JavaScript

JavaScript is the expansive functional side of web development, a vast programming language that has gone through years of constant development and change. Here are numerous resources I've found across the web. You can go ahead and filter them by library or framework if you like.

Filter by Technology

Pick a framework or a library

Angular

Visit

Angular is Google's framework for building Single Page Applications. The framework is written in Typescript, a superset of JavaScript. It allows you to build your web apps in reusable components and delivers high performant web experiences.

jQuery

Visit

jQuery is JavaScript's most famous library. Though it's use has diminished in recent years, it's still holds a lot of utility and is found in many projects. As a web developer, understanding jQuery will still be useful. This is the official website for the library.

Try jQuery

Visit

Try jQuery is an interactive site that teaches the basics of jQuery, focusing on event management and DOM traversal.

React

Visit

React is one of the fastest growing single page application frameworks. React uses JSX to write reusable components. It manages state, (and can do further with Redux) and helps you develop complex UIs easily.

React Native

Visit

React Native is a framework that allows you to use React to construct mobile apps on Android and iOS.

Vue.js

Visit

Vue is described by Gregg Pollack of VueMastery.com as "an approachable, versatile and performant JavaScript framework that allows you to make a more maintainable and testable codebase."

Vue Mastery

Visit

Vue Mastery contains a whole course load of materials that will teach you Vue, which is a small, yet powerful and performant framework for web apps.

Electron

Visit

Electron is a JavaScript framework that allows you to build desk top apps using HTML, CSS and JavaScript. VSCode, Atom, and Github Desktop are a few examples of what Electron can do.

Eloquent JavaScript

Visit

Eloquent JavaScript is an online book that . . . There is also a physical book you can pick up, if you're the type who likes holding paper.

JavaScript 30

Visit

JavaScript 30 is one of Wes Bos's courses. It is a free course that challenges you to 30 minutes of JavaScript coding a day. He provides you with a small project to make and challenges you to make it yourself and then goes over the solution in clear detail.

JS Tips

Visit

JS Tips is a collection of JavaScript tips that will help you be a better programmer.

Christian Engvall

Visit

Christian Engvall is a software developer. His site has numerous articles about web development

Node.js

Visit

Node.js is a JavaScript runtime that can run on the console or the server. Node.js enables us to use JavaScript to write server-side scripts.

Node School

Visit

Node School is a website with courses that will teach you Node.js.

Coursetro

Visit

Coursetro has numerous courses on JavaScript and various frameworks. It has a mixture of free and premium courses.

Phaser

Visit

Phaser is a JavaScript framework that uses HTML canvas to write games.

egghead

Visit

egghead delivers courses on JavaScript and many of its frameworks and libraries in concise courses that get to the point.

Codeburst

Visit

Codeburst contains a vast number of web development courses ranging from basic JavaScript and jQuery, to frameworks like React and Node.

Lodash

Visit

Lodash is a popular JavaScript utility library, known for its speed and modularity. You can download the entire Lodash library and apply it to your project, or cherry pick specific functions. Lodash also has an fp library to support functional programming.

Underscore

Visit

Underscore provides a whole mess of utilities for JavaScript programmers. Underscore provides over 100 helper functions without extending built in objects.

Next.js

Visit

Next.js is a small framework for React apps, designed for static and server-side rendered applications. Next.js makes React applications simple.

Job Ready JavaScript

Visit

This is a guide to help any potential web developer to be job ready with his or her JavaScript abilities.

Scotch School

Visit

Scotch is a subscription based site that teaches web development. They focus on building apps and teaching the why behind the code. Their projects will also help you build out your portfolio.
